info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 10:57PM EST until January 11 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of Henderson County in western North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 1000 AM EST Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1050 PM EST, Rain gauges recorded rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches in the past 24 hours over the Mud Creek and Bat Fork Creek stream basins. The runoff from this recent heavy rainfall continues to produce very elevated water levels in these basins around the Hendersonville area. Flooding is ongoing in the warning area and is likely to continue through the early morning hours Wednesday. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hendersonville, Flat Rock, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Valley Hill, East Flat Rock and Dana. - Flooding is most likely along Mud Creek at North Main Street in Hendersonville. Significant flooding will continue in currently inundated areas, with several feet of water likely in and around William H. King Memorial Park and Jackson Park. Waters may approach first-floor levels of some buildings, but it does appear as if Mud Creek is cresting late this evening. Flooding is also likely occurring along Bat Fork Creek, with New Hope Road, Dana Road, and Tracy Grove Road likely impacted. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
